title: FT5 cablechain removal and new pieces

description.text:
New FT8 : just for putting the right tension on the belt (and to carry the stepper of course) is a bit shorter since the endstop function has now a separate piece.

To fix the cable ends there are 2 new pieces.
A new FT9 on top of the stepper. Very small and leaving almost the complete surface of the stepper free as heatsink.
A new piece on top of the printhead.

I fixed the cable using the sliding attachments from this design

A live view in this video

Printing
I printed all pieces in ABS. This is important for FT8&FT9 since they are in contact with a hot stepper!
Nozzle 0,6mm, 0,4mm layers, 60% infill. A bit of support for the holes.

title: Easily removable prop guard for Moskito 70

description.text:
A prop guard for the Furious FPV Moskito 70 brushless micro quadcopter. It only mounts with 4 screws, and there is no need to remove the camera and standoffs every time you want to take the prop guard off or put it back on. I have not yet printed or tried using this part, so please let me know the results if you do. I want to try printing this in TPU, which I believe will make it nearly indestructible compared to the original one that Furious FPV supplies. However, if the TPU is not rigid enough, my next choice would be PETG or something similar. PLA would probably work for a short while, but would break very easily.

I recommend printing it upside down, probably with supports.

author: makerpetri

description.text:
To avoid Z-height differences between left and right side of the bed I set up an interlockiong mechanism between both threaded rods.

The pulleys are all made using F625ZZ bearings. Longer bolts through the pulley are M5x30 and are fixed in the 2040-profile.
You will need :
a long GT2 loop that I ordered from Adafruit
2x500mm of 2020 profile to carry the rods
1x500mm 2040 profile for the steppers
2x straight metal stepper supports
4 x 100mm 2020 pieces to receive the 2 larger 2020 pieces and some corner pieces to fix all 20xx to the chassis
2 extra GT2 pulleys for the threaded rods (8mm internal diameter)
sufficient time and some engineering skills are recommended.

Mounting recommendations
Lower the Y-rails until they match with the top of the steel rods. Keep a couple of mm between the rods and the profile.
Install the rods with supports (and the bed!) without fixing them Don't forget to get the timing belts over the threaded rods on beforehand!!!
With the rods in place run the bed to the top position and fix the top supports to the 2020-profile.
Run the bed to the bottom position and align the supports AND the supporting 2020-profiles do this a couple of times until everything runs smooth.
Fix all supports.
Install the stepper.
Install the pullleys on the 2040 profile with a 80mm 2020 profile.
Run the long belt along its path. Loosen the locking screws on the GT2 pulleys on the threaded rods and adjust tension with one of the pulleys on the 2040 profile. DO NOT overtension!
Adjust both sides of the bed measuring from the bed to a point on the X-gantry.
Fix the locking screws of the GT2-pulleys.

A live view in this video

comments.text:
And why keep TWO motors ? Just remove them and replace the yellow pulley by ONE motor ! At least you have seen that these motors get out of synch, many people here if not most keep denying this evidence, an insult to good engineering practice ! 2 steppers 2 lead screws Z Is a MAJOR design error seen in almost all 3D printers ! Not only it is bad but even more costly !
Oh, true it is symmetric and more appealing to the eye ! FUNCTION MUST ALWAYS PREAVAIL on appearance !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: and on the yy too.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Of course you are right about that. It reduces the number of mechanical components, would make it simpler and more reliable...
But I have my doubts about the power one motor can develop. I do have friction and the bed is not that lightweight.
Both motors are also connected in series so they are already electrically very much in sync.
They do not move much so heat is not an issue. A larger stepper like a NEMA23 could also be a solution but then I have height issues.
Oh : I didn't see the motors get out of sync left/right... It is more me. I do not remove the sheet of glass to remove the pieces. I remove them while still in place ...
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
One NEMA17 40mm should be plenty enough unless you have really excessive friction which should be reduced as it is certainly due to misalignment and is detrimental.
You can measure the torque required with a scale, a string around a pulley. You can also reduce the current till you miss steps and see how much it is and determine the torque from the motor spec. On my Geetech Prusa, although the X gantry is about 1kg, I use one Nema17 40 mm buth a 34mm would be enough. The torque required is 10 N.cm, two TR8 8 mm lead.
comments.author: WalterSKW

comments.text:
So Arthur, I did the test and will keep the setup. Good you mentioned your Geetech setup. That convinced me to test it.
I rearranged a bit the pulleys adjusted some height an that's it. Made a small test run with Z-moves from 10 to 300mm and back. After 30 minutes the stepper remains hand warm. Will post a video. Thanks for your remark!
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Friction or binding isn't an issue. I didn't try it yet with one stepper.
But it is indeed worth doing that. Since it is quite flexible to reconfigure now, I can do a test later this week.

title: X wing crit reminder counters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
John wanted some crit reminder counters and had drawn up some. Suggested I could 3d print some so had a tweak and play in Sketchup and here they are.

The stl files need the base.stl in first if you are printing single colour. There is a zip file with all of them in.

The thing files are set for two colour printing and are also in a single zip file for convenience.
The All crits.thing file has all the counters laid out on it but you may find it tricky as I had several attempts using this as far ones kept popping off during printing.

Dual printing can be a pain and needs aligning, on mine I keep getting blobs on one side that is why the second colour is more on top and not inside as they printed badly.

Included counters are as follows :-

  • 0 pilot skill
  • all crits
  • don't crash
  • minus 1 attack dice
  • minus 1 agility
  • no actions
  • no sharp turns
  • no straight manoeuvres
  • console fire
  • skip attack
  • white manoeuvre gets stress

As always drop some feedback or a photo of ones you have made and have a look at my other x-wing priniting bits.

Printer:

CTC dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

had the bed heated also as all done in PLA

If printing them all together ensure you have good adheshion as they can pop off.

I have a glass bed and applied some extra pritt stick after 2 failed attempts with counters popping off.

title: Nerf Artemis Pump Action Grip V2

description.text:
This is the 2nd pump action grip I made for the Nerf Rival Artemis XVII-3000.
The first one was a bit to skinny for my taste.
I used a set of M6 nuts and bolts that I salvaged form.
If you want to use different nuts and bolts follow the link in the how I designed this block.

Edit: Compared to the V1 the default orientation on the bed has not changed, but I think it's better / easier to print with the middle facing down. ( on both versions )
Since: 1 The guide rail does not experience pulling forces. 2 The nuts and bolts will compress on the layers instead of potentially splitting the layers.

For strength I went with 5 outlines and 1mm of top and bottom layers.
Support was 33% sparse and 55% dense

Sliced with S3D
The support material can be removed without to much effort.

title: Double-Bobbin for Ashford Joy Spinning Wheel

description.text:
As I always wanted a bobbin with two seperate chambers for spinning and plying afterwards, I designed this double-bobbin for my Ashford Joy spinning wheel.
With this bobbin, both halfs of the bobbin can be filled with singles.
And afterwards they can be plied together and the yarn will fill a complete bobbin.
The designed bobbin has a coupling part, so on the spinning wheel both halfs turn together. And on a lazy cate the coupling can be removed and both halfs turn alone, so that they can be plyed together.
A complete bobbin printed is in development and will be available here soon.

I used IGUS bearings MFI-0405-06 and the design of the bobbin does not need drilling if your printer is well adjusted.
Both pars "Zwischenscheibe" and "Doppelspule" fit together without clueing in my case, but they can be clued if neccessary.

Please note: as Nylon and PLA seem to interact with electrostatical charging I use a hemp string as brake for the bobbin.
Printed in 0,05mm layer height it has a smooth surface for the brake tension string.

Sorry for the yarn: I can spin better, but for this test I wasn´t as concentrated on the yarn quality :-)

title: Ultimaker 2 Top Enclosure - Remixed - reoriented and split

description.text:
This is a 1:1 remix of Ultimaker 2 Top Enclosure, meaning I haven't modified the parts.

So what have I done to make it a remix?

Changes:

  • Reoriented all parts, so you don't have to experiment with the best orientation.
  • Split the part Corner3Side5X into Corner3Side5X-large_part and Corner3Side5X-small_part and oriented them for easy printing.

Printer:

My Crossbot design

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.25

Infill:

10

Notes:

The only part needing support is D_CornerBackRight.
It might look a bit odd, how it is put on end, but it is in order to avoid having suports in hard to remove places.

If you print all pieces together, you can raise support angle to 75% to avoid having support put in unnessecarily for the other pieces.

You can drill ø4 holes in the printed parts to make the assembly easier if they are a bit small.

Parts needed

  • 30x M4*20mm screws
  • 30x M4 nuts
  • Acrylic plates or similar (5mm thick)
  • 1x 316*200mm ---> Back side
  • 1x 326*200mm ---> Front side
  • 2x 440*200mm ---> Left and Right sides
  • 1x 445*326mm ---> Top side
  • 1x 210*97mm ---> Back down side

Drilling holes and assembly

  • Be careful : remove the protection plastics from your acrylic plates after drilling all the holes to avoid a lot of scratches etc.
  • Put the 3D parts in place on the acrylic plates and drill the ø4 holes.
  • Start assembling and be careful not to overtighten the screws as it can both ruin your printed parts and the acrylic plates

title: M4 Airsoft RAS Keymod Rail
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After playing a couple of games with my M4 AEG I found that the plastic handguards were just not sturdy enough for me and looked a bit too stock.

I then sat down and took my M4 apart and studied the Delta ring and gas tube connection, after a while of measuring and searching Google for reference images I came up with this 10" RAS Keymod Rail.

It attaches right onto the threads on the upper receiver and just screws tight, and it can be held in place with the gas tube. Alternatively you can use a rail riser or optic as I have done in the pictures to keep slight pressure on the rail as not to unscrew (it already is fairly tight).
The rail is actually free floating, but I designed a mounted suppressor that screws OVER the outer barrel extension to give extra strength to the rail and keep the inner barrel secure.
The suppressor has standard 14mm CCW threads.

For adding rail segments I suggest my keymod rail segments design.

Printer:

Gemstock - Azurite

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Make sure you print it in a sturdy filament like PLA or ABS, others might not hold up to the weight of the rifle and might sag/bend.
Also make sure your cooling and retraction settings are properly dialed in.

Mounting the rail

Disassemble your current rail/handguard so that only your receiver and outer barrel are left.
Screw the rail onto the threads of the receiver whilst slightly unscrewing in between to loosen the threads of the rail a little.
Once in place, mount the gas tube or optic to keep the rail in place.
Lastly mount the suppressor onto the outer barrel and into the rail by just simply screwing it on.

Update

I have just also uploaded a 7" and a 12" version alongside of the original 10", for those that have a CQB length airsoft replica and for those that have a rifle length barrel.

Update 2

I have on special request of Phreqq made a 4" version for those that have no need for their barrel to compensate anything. ;-)

I also made some changes to the threading section on mention of simonvez who told me that some barrel types don't fit great in my original design, thus I changed the barrel opening to 24mm on his recommendation.

title: GASB One Bubble Canopy and Lower Cowl

description.text:
Additional items I made for the GASB One flying wing.
Bubble canopy to afford a little more height in the battery bay and a lower cowl so the ESC can be placed outside.
I made slits either side of the forward lip around the battery bay and used CA to attach the canopy tags to the underside of the canopy and line them up with the slits cut in the nose.

title: Halbach Array Linear Direct 3D Printer Extruder Drive
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
An extruder with a stepper motor is used in my Pusa I3 and also in almost all 3D printers.
I decided to develop a lighter extruder drive based on a 3-phase linear actuator with a magnetic Halbach array. It is designed to directly replace NEMA17 in any 3D printer.
I wanted to use VCA (Voice Coil Actuator) as a drive, but VCA are very expensive and weaker than the drive with 3-phase coils and a magnetic Halbach array.

https://youtu.be/aeM0KQuF120

Features of the extruder drive:

  • High Force to Weight Ratio
  • High continuous and peak forces
  • Weight 4.2oz (119 grams)
  • High Accelerations
  • Halbach Array magnetic system
  • Scotch Yoke mechanism.

For a full description of the drive, see here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Linear-Direct-3D-Printer-Extruder-Drive-Fusion-360/

We need 5 Neodymium Rare Earth magnets 5X5X25mm N42 magnets
or use compound magnets, they will need 10 pieces.
https://www.indigo.com/magnets/rare_earth/blocks/neodymium-slab-magnet-25x5x2.5mm.html

The diameter of the wire can be changed if a larger force is required, but the consumption current will increase.
Tests with a 3-phase bridge driver showed that the drive effort is sufficient to operate as an extruder drive.
This is an experimental device, work on it continues.

Printer:

prusa i3

Infill:

0,15

comments.text: See other comments.
comments.author: Revenger

comments.text: Maybe I'm missing something but how do you get torque at the output from the scotch yoke when the linear actuator is at it's extremes of travel?
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text:
Good question!.
This mechanism works poorly at the extreme points. I consider the application of two Halbach arrays but with magnets of 20 mm. The total weight of the device does not increase, but it will make it possible to scotch yokes at an angle of 90 degrees. This is the solution of the problem of extreme points
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text:
Your linear motor construction looks great.
I love the elegance of a rotary electric motor, especially the 3-phase brushless motors used in radio control. I wanted to use them on my printer years ago, the challenge becomes melding stepper motor control with brushless motor control. I think that is where the next major work should be undertaken. Step angles and force are then equal per cycle. STMicroelectronics have a lot of motor control starter kits. However, without lots of magnets and coils(like our stepper motors), power to weight ratio suffers without gearing to allow a higher motor speed.
comments.author: TanyaAkinora

comments.text: This is interesting.  It actually has enough torque to push the filament?  You come up with some of the most interesting stuff. =)
comments.author: cdl1701

comments.text: The torque depends only on the current through the coils. It is sufficient to work as a drive. But optimization of the drive and electronic part is required.
comments.author: cdl1701

description.text:
This is a Front Suspension Mount for a Tamiya RC DT-03 Racing Fighter. However, it may fit on other RC models. I designed this after my mount snapped following a heavy collision.

I printed this twice ,1st with an infill of 40%, and 2nd with an infill of 100%. They were both surprisingly very strong, but the 100% infill is obviously much better, and is stronger than the original piece. You need the original screws to mount it on to the car.

It took my printer about 35 minutes to print. Please comment on how you found this model. Any questions welcome.

First I made the feet with the center of the pads at the crosspoint of the printer walls, But I didn't li like it. So I made some other feet with a more tangential design. This looked much better on the printer.

description.text:
This is a remix of the part by JanBeckman, thanks for your design.

Currently I'm printing these so this is a beta but it's designed to finish sealing the door of my Ikea Stuva enclosure after installing a draught excluding seal (which I bought here https://www.amazon.co.uk/KING-DO-WAY-Soundproofing-Weatherstrip/dp/B017XEE70E).

As I keep my enclosure in a single brick skin garage it is cold all year round in the U.K. this and a few other upgrades are planned to help improve my ABS printing.

UPDATES
Version 1: The U-shaped catch broke on multiple uses!
Version 2: Re-designed U-shaped catch with braces and removed the odd design decision by the original author to effectively make it print in 3 connected pieces - Will update with findings once printed and attached

Very simple thick washer to improve the design of a great electric corkscrew with a very simple design flaw. Load when cork is extracted is put on three thin pieces of plastic which break off resulting in collar and cork getting stuck inside corkscrew body. Addition of large spacer puts all load on main body of corkscrew instead of small plastic stops - problem cured. Two repaired so far successfully.
Remove bottom black collar, slide out clear plastic spacer and add new spacer between bottom of spring and top of clear plastic spacer. Re-assemble

title: DronePlane
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a project that combines a drone with an airplane.The Idea is to use 5 motors instead of 4.The 5th motor is for forwarding motion after the drone has done its lift off and get to acquired altitude.The lift motors can then be gradually step down and the 5th motor use to drive the drone like a plane.
The design is constructed to be as universal as possible to accommodate as many types of motors and PCB and batteries as possible.
After prints you will probably need to sand down parts to fit.
You Might need springs and small ball bearings for landing gear but the rest can be printed with PLA or ABS

title: XMachines Lorei fan duct (easy mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I modified the "fan duct" design for easier installation. There are only the bottom two screw mounts left. I also wanted to get rid of the tiny hex nuts on the back so the holes are 2.6mm in diameter in the model and I used a 3mm thread cutter to finish them off.

The two holes are tilted by 1.5° on purpose so the upper part of the duct should be pressed slightly agains the fan to counter any gap.

Thanks to dulfe for the original design:
Lorei Filament Cooler by dulfe (http://www.thingiverse.com/dulfe)
Published on February 13, 2017
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2106906)

Printer:

XMachines Lorei DUO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

200µ

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print the design with the flat surface on the bed. Support is optional but might give you a nicer finish on the inside.
I would recommend printing 4 outer shells because of the thread cutting that is needed to make the original 3mm screws fit.

Because of the higher temps I would recommend against PLA. ABS works fine for me.

author: Pawloosw

description.text:
This is a replica of the radio knobs found on a vintage french radio. The original knob was molded, probably Bakelite[TM]. As knobs were damaged, I redesigned the knob in OpenSCAD in a few minutes.
To be fully functional, a set screw shaft collar with a M4 set screw is needed to hold the knob tight on the axis. You can use a collar with german DIN705A with 16mm outer diameter and drill the hole to 12mm. Using a lathe this is done in very short time.

Original collar outer diameter 16mm, inner diameter 12.5mm, height 7mm. Pointed set screw length about 9mm. As I was reusing the original parts, all dimensions are for this type of collar.

Currently I have made two test prints with red filament. The destination colour is dark brown/black.

Printer:

Cheap chinese prusa clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Used Filament Kaisertech ABS 245°C.
Slic3r 1.3 rc8
Support for outer ring only, inner structures do not need support.
3 perimeters, 3 solid layers, top infill concentric

Remove support

Remove support from outer ring. Sand the surface where the support was removed if necessary.

Acetone vapor bath

Put on a support in a closed container with some acetone to smooth the surface. Let it smooth until the surface gehts shiny and smooth. See https://youtu.be/Xj53P2YzYGM for a demonstation.
If you leave it too long, the knob will get soft and distorted.

Add front plate

Use a thin aluminium or stainless steel plate and glue it into the cavity on the top. Use your favourite surface finish before glueing it.

This is my zortrax solution to side load the filament. The original filament mount is on the back and the struggle was real. At the top is room for the filament tube or a screw hole to mount an optional filament monitor (to be designed).

This filament mount can support big rols, and different inner diameters with optional (to be designed) adapters. I use a little grease on the filament bar to ensure smooth rolling.

The holes to mount the top to the bottom are for m3 screws.

Mine is printed with sparkling grey PLA.

I did use 2 designs from thingiverse, one for the bottom and the filament tube holder but unfortunately I forgot to write down the authors, my apologies. If someone finds the originals I will include them to recognize their work

title: 20 Series 2020 Misumi T-Slot Rail - 10mm to 600mm Lengths

description.text:
This is a remix of the 20 Series Misumi Aluminum Extrusion 2020 T-Slot rail project. I've included STL files for 2020 rails in 60 different lengths ranging from 10 mm to 600 mm, in 10 mm increments. I've needed several different lengths for different projects over the last couple of years and it takes a bit of work to make STL files for different lengths when needed, so I decided to just make all the different lengths one day to save time in the future. I figured other people might need these too, so I decided to remix this project and provide all of these 2020 T-slot rail STL files pre-made and ready to print. Thanks and respect to beverageexpert for creating the original project! I hope this is project helpful to you too!

The lengths of 20 Series 2020 T-Slot rail in the included STL files is as follows:

2020_10mm.stl - 10 mm of 20 Series Misumi T-Slot rail
2020_20mm.stl - 20 mm of 20 Series Misumi T-Slot rail

These 2020 T-Slot Rails should be printed standing straight up when possible. The STL files should be set to the correct printing direction already.

Project Credits

I’d like to give credit and my utmost respect for these STL designs to all the people that made this project possible. Credit for this work should go to the following people and entities:

  1. To Bryan (beverageexpert - http://www.thingiverse.com/beverageexpert/about) for Bryan's original Misumi aluminum extrusion 2020 profile design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280318.

  2. To Geoffrey L. Griffith (Me – GeoffreyG - http://www.thingiverse.com/GeoffreyG/designs) for Geoffrey’s modified STL files to provide lengths for all the different sizes: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2254024.

  3. And last, but most importantly, Thingiverse.com for being so incredibly amazingly AWESOME and hosting this unending repository of knowledge and product designs for the world to use 100% free of charge. Your contributions are the most important in this great endeavor and I’m eternally grateful for the services you provide!

This is a version of Skimbal's Turtle Shell Racer High Power, slightly modified to work with the New Bright #1680 model RC car.  The original called for #2424 which does not seem to be available any longer.  #1680 is available at Target as of this writing (May 2012)  
All the original files have been run through netfabb to fix slicing errors.  There are a couple of new files and/or modifications needed - see the instructions.

Follow the very well written directions in the original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10526 with the following differences: Print the rear wheels at 1.25 scale (125%) in order to make the tires fit well. Print 2 of the supplied nut collars and use them to step down the recesses for the rear wheel nuts back to original size. The nut collar was done in SketchUp. Use the provided steering linkage instead of scavenging the one from the New Bright car. I don't see any reason why this can't be a printable part, and besides the dimensions on #1680 are slightly different so you can't use it as is. Find the source for it at https://tinkercad.com/things/8j18bxwGVZe/ I added a 1 Spike STL so you can more easily print the 5 spikes required for the blue shell. The suggested ESC does not seem to be available anywhere. I used a "071 50A 400W Brushed ESC W/Reverse" from eBay. The zip file contains all the individual STL & SKP files attached to this thing for easier download.

title: Number Plate Ikea Kallax Light

description.text:
I upcycled my old german moped number plate by using it as a heatsink / mounting plate for a LED light mounted to an IKEA Kallax.

The LED is a sumbulbs 94x50mm 12V COB
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-50-7mm-3W-5W-COB-bar-wall-desk-lamp-lighting-source-LED-chip-on-board/32722604378.html

I used a 12V power adapter but it run a little hot. Since I don't had a current limiter at hand I used a diode to drop the Voltage by 0.6V.

The number plate with is 107.6mm but it could be scaled in X to accommodate different sizes.

The front part is printed bottom down. To make the impossible overhang work without support add a pause into the .gcode at 3mm ( M25 ). When the printer pauses insert the number plate and press continue.

The back part is printed on the side (no support needed)

author: d4zza

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5mO69klGNgs

The HyperCube Evolution 3D Printer is a CoreXY printer inspired by the excellent HyperCube 3D Printer developed by Tech2C. The belt arrangement on that printer was the neatest CoreXY arrangement that I have seen.

I have leveraged the great work that Tech2C has done to refine his design and incorporated this with my own further development to reduce the number of printed parts and simplify the build.

Design goals for the HyperCube Evolution 3D Printer:

  1. Increase the stiffness of the printer to further improve / reduce vibration artefacts.

    • 3030 extrusion used for the frame
    • 2020 extrusion used for the build platform frame
    • 8mm diameter X rails
    • 10mm diameter Y rails
    • 12mm diameter Z rails
  2. Minimise the size of the printer for the chosen build volume.
    • Parametric CAD design in Autodesk Inventor
    • Excel spreadsheet provided to allow for customised printer size

The prototype printer, with a build volume of 300 x 300 x 300, met with all expectation but did show some small bed vibrations when printing at high speed due to the large bed and counter levered design. Therefore, two build options are available. A single Z axis version for smaller build platforms and a double Z axis version for larger beds or those wishing for a rock solid build platform.

The Evolution also features a quick attach X carriage to allow for interchangeable tools e.g. the extruder mount and a DTI mount for tramming the build platform.

More to come over the next few weeks as I'm awaiting parts for upgrade the prototype to use the double Z axis, and also the parts to convert my Geetech Prusa i3 into another HyperCube Evolution.

Facebook Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/Hypercubeevolution/

Changelog:

20.04.2017 Configuration file updated, multiple size Bed Brackets added
22.04.2017 BOM added
23.04.2017 Introduction video added https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rctCsUGnX8&feature=youtu.be
23.04.2017 Added 4 variations of Y carriage to suit different combinations of 8mm and 10mm rails. Plus bearing clamps to suit. Note - current X carriage only suits LM8UU bearings. An adaptor will be needed to use 10mm bushings.
30.04.2017 Error found in spreadsheet which resulted in 10mm rails being 30mm too long. Version 1.2 uploaded.
09.05.2017 Version 1.1 Z Axis Linear Rail Bracket - Double Z - Left & Right.
13.05.2017 Version 1.1 Z Nut Bracket - modified for easier assembly
13.05.2017 Z Nut Bracket for T10 leadscrew added
27.05.2017 Configuration file updated to include part print list (note that some part versions are still not available)
02.06.2017 Repetier configuration file uploaded
17.06.2017 40mm bed bracket added
17.06.2017 v1.1 versions of XY Stepper Mount and Idler Mount added which have slotted screw holes for different L brackets. v1.0 versions remain for those who don't need the slot.
17.06.2017 v1.1 of XY Stepper Mount and Idler Mount for 8mm diameter Y linear rails
18.06.2017 v1.4 configuration file added.. Thanks to Nicolas Harscoat for adding the shaft selector which then determines the part versions to be printed.
01.07.2017 CAD files uploaded for v1.0 as a pack and go. So the assembly should work. Note that some published parts are now v1.0+, but these files should get people going.
22.07.2017 Mounts for Full Graphic Controller added

comments.text:
When using openoffice calc, The Vlookup for the cell c24-c27 are invalid, so I changed it to make it work.
=VLOOKUP($Configuration.$G$15;$Configuration.$N$6:$R$11;2;0)
=VLOOKUP($Configuration.$G$15;$Configuration.$N$6:$R$11;3;0)
=VLOOKUP($Configuration.$G$15;$Configuration.$N$6:$R$11;4;0)
=VLOOKUP($Configuration.$G$15;$Configuration.$N$6:$R$11;5;0)

comments.author: FabioAlmeida1996

comments.text: IMO a 400w bed will pull too much thru the on board mosfet of the ramps 1.4 so get an external mosfet!!
comments.author: FabioAlmeida1996

comments.text:
Hi Fabio Mine is working at 24 volt,
De-solder the fuse which says 16 volts on it and replace it by an automotiv fuse. Look in youtube.
You need 24 volts fans and a 24 volt hotend.
My heated bed was getting his current via an external MOSFET board. It would burn the original mosfet on the Ramps.
comments.author: FabioAlmeida1996

comments.text: Do you have to use the 24V hot end?  For the fans can you just use the fan extender module?  In process of building mine, so you response is appreciated!
comments.author: HB9DOD

comments.text: You can use everthing on 12 volt, I never used the fan extender module. It depends what components you have. My experience is that is easier to go on everything with 24 volts but you can use the bed on 24 volts and the rest on 12. You need 2 powersupplies in that case. The bed on 12 volt takes ages to warm up to 80 degrees and higher

comments.text:
Hello,
Note: I am new to 3d printing and these are some of my noob questions.
I am building a modified version of this hypercube and I want to make sure I am doing things right. I am thinking about using a 300x200mm heated bed. for the bed itself, is a pcb and aluminum sheet with insulation such as http://www.ebay.com/itm/300x200mm-Aluminum-Heated-Bed-Build-Plate-3D-Printer-RepRap-Prusa-i3-Full-Kit-/321998961595?hash=item4af8a23bbb:g:sA0AAOSwrFJZyU-3 be sufficient? Will a single z axis be able to support/move the bed and if so, what type of nema 17 motor will it require? If you recommend using dual z axis, how is the alignment? Also, any advice on using tmc 2100 stepper drivers? I am thinking about using these stepper drivers https://www.reprap.me/stepstick-tmc2100.html Will they use the same gcode as the a4988 drivers? Also, If I were to use igus bearings https://www.reprap.me/drylinr-igus-rj4jp-01-10-10mm-linear-bearing.html can I still use steel rods or do I have to use aluminum. I am considering using carbon fiber for the x gantry, does anyone have experience with cutting carbon fiber. How do these belts http://www.ebay.com/itm/2M-GATES-6mm-2GT-GT2-RF-Fiber-Glass-Reinforced-Rubber-Timing-Belt-for-3D-Printer-/141938661911?hash=item210c341a17:g:7IIAAOSwSzdXBOUN compare the polyurethane belts everyone is using. Does anyone have experience with a Radds 1.5 and arduino due configuration? How does that compare to the beaglbone and replicape combo? Has anyone run octoprint on a beaglebone, while using it as a controller board for a 3d printer? Can 24v psu run the stepper drivers at a higher speed while maintaining the same accuracy? Final question for now, how much does the weight of the x gantry affect print speed? Second to last question, does a higher holding torque motor mean higher speeds? I am trying to find ways to move the xgantry faster, which would result in faster printing speeds. If I were to use aluminum vs carbon rods, could I still get 200mm/s+ print speeds?
comments.author: Terrybyte

comments.text: 300x200 bed - sure it'll be fine. Keep in mind its a 12V heatbed so you will need a beefy power supply (i.e. 12V 40A) and some very thick power wiring, like 10AWG or so.
comments.author: Terrybyte

comments.text: Thank you very much for your reply. I will buy my parts soon. Any experience with purchasing from reprap.me? Also, is the firmware provided by scorr3d good for the due and radds/azsmz combo or is there another place I have to go to get that gcode/firmware?

comments.text: I actually printed 2020 at first, got fed up with it, and then just ordered 3030. I threaded 100mm long 1mm thick single walled printed 2020 onto 5/16inch threaded rods. Everything was going fine until I decided to bring the entire batch of printed 2020 to 100°C in the oven to add a bit of ease threading in the 5/16inch threaded rods. I watched a video that said you lose a bit on the Z axis doing this baking without mention of warping. This baking warped the printed 2020 - I should have known better and tested a single piece first. Perhaps it was the single walled nature of my specific parts that induced this warping. I still finished assembling a 400mm x 400mm frame with the printed 2020 which "seems" fairly rigid yet I believe only Salvador Dali would use it as a 3D printer... My experience/exposure is assembling a single DIY 3D printer kit and have no example of what acceptable rigidity is - thus I just went ahead and ordered the 3030. I may add some thoughts on this when I've learned more. For me, the time and cost of printing the 2020 was not worth attempting to circumvent the aluminum 3030. At the very least, it gave me some experience to share. The individual 100mm PLA printed 2020 extrusion is exremely tough and rigid by the way.
comments.author: Korbal

comments.text: I, like many others, are very impressed with this design and it ticks many of the boxes for my next build.  I, like many others, can't help but my own stamp on the design.  I have a couple of printers with dual Z-axis steppers and I have always wondered how I will know if they get out of sync due to lost steps.  Of course, if it gets too bad, the Z axis will bind but a few lost steps could go unnoticed.  So, before I order the parts for my Evo, I'm considering using a dual Z axis design with a single stepper motor and a 6mm GT2 belt between drive pulleys on the two acme leadscrews to synchronize them.  I don't know that this is really necessary, but I also tell myself it can't hurt.  In order to pull this off, I'll need a GT2 closed loop belt which comes in fixed lengths.  Can anyone with an assembled Evo tell me what the center to center dimension is between the leadscrews on a dual Z configuration?
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: I just got mine working. I am adding the end stops right now. I have a third lead screw, and once I get a smaller belt, I will move the motor inside the printer and attach it to the bed as well giving me 3 mount points to life the bed from. I may test removing the smooth rods. Currently i have a dual Z 300x300 version. The belt that is attached right now is 1140 GT2 6mm. The pulleys are 60 tooth pulleys. https://photos.app.goo.gl/T1mvyH9Qpz5m5bXF3
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: If driving two lead screws from a singe stepper, You may want to do with a less aggressive thread pitch. Maybe a TR8x2 instead of the common T8x8... That is four time the leverage (or rotational travel) for the same z-travel. My $.02...

comments.text: 1- the brass inserts are cool in theory, but in practice it's very easy to pull them out, e.g: when tightening the screws on the XY joiners (the y bearing holder on the original wasn't a bad design with the bolt and nut assembly), or the one in the middle of the x carriage. There are places where the brass inserts are perfectly fine, such as in the idler pulley holders or the rod end clamps because there's plastic in between them and they're acting as nuts. Where they're doing the job of a tapped hole (e.g: xy joiner) is where they're not so fine, because of the insert-pulling action I described before. In that area, they're also too close to the surface that touches the bearings; when you're inserting them with the soldering iron it's easy to make bumps on that surface, which requires a bit of sanding down in order to fit the bearings. The y axis bearings also give plenty of room for tabs for through-bolts and nuts.
comments.author: aroldorosenberg

comments.author: brunofporto

comments.text:
If you ever build the Evolution, you will know, why there are 4 Z-rods.
And the 4 12mm rods are definately NOT overkill. They make sure, that the bed is a rock solid construction, that does not bend, twist or otherwise move, where it should not move, except up and down. The construction is so rigid, that you can move the bed up and down with connecting only ONE of the motors (I actually did that for testing purposes).
If you look into Scotts construction carefully, you can see, that he put a lot of thoughts into this and that everything has a reason, why its is build like this and not otherways.
When you see the flimsy and whacky bed constructions of some other printers, you know why they always have issues with bed leveling, wobbling and such. NOT with the EVO. I leveled my EVO only ONCE after I finished building it. Now the EVO is printing for some 2 months now WITHOUT any bed leveling at all.
And still prints like a charm.
So believe me, you rather go with an "overkill" (which it isnt) construction like ours, than always fuddle with a whacky bed.
I would alway suggest, that you first build the EVO with the original design and if you then still see needs for "improvement", then go ahead. Of course you are free to build however you like, but maybe you give it a thought, since I already have a working EVO for some time now, I have built 2 other printers before, and the EVO is BY FAR the best
comments.author: Sirage

Scott
I have found there is an issue with the configurator for people that are using a coupler between the stepper and lead screw.
Of course it will extend the lead screw 10-15 cm ish. A bit of a duh moment I wish I had realized before hand.
So either the lead screw needs to be shorter or the frame and z rod guides need to be that much longer.
comments.author: warham

comments.text: Yes, if using a coupler then some extra z height will be required to compensate for them. Good idea for the configurator. Will put it on the to do list.
comments.author: warham

comments.text: What lengths did you get? I'm about to order parts myself.
comments.author: warham

comments.text: This is only if you will be using a coupler, if you use a stepper with a lead screw built in such as Scott used the excel file is fine.
comments.author: ThatPlayer

comments.text: I believe the specs of the stepper motor should have the length of the shaft. The coupler itself should not add any height to the z-axis setup I believe. The stepper motor I am looking into buying says 20mm, so I think I will extend my Z-axis configuration by 20mm? (300mm + 20mm) and then use a 330 (300mm + the 30mm it says to add) sound okay?
comments.author: warham

comments.text:
If your coupler allows the lead screw and motor shaft to touch then you only need to account for the length of the motor shaft. If not then it seems you are looking at the motor shaft length plus the gap in the coupler between the shaft and lead screw. Mine has a gap of around 1cm which is enough to not allow the Z rods to reach the lower clamps without turning them upside down. I cant lower the upper rails to accommodate because the lead screw will stick up too high at that point. So I suggest Z height plus maybe 15mm ish lead screw but not 30mm.
If the gap in the model is correct there should be room to play since the shaft and the coupler should eat up around 30mm. My build only has a few mm to play with though.
comments.author: ThatPlayer

comments.text: Do you mean 15mm or 15cm? 15cm seems like alot.
comments.author: warham

comments.text: whups MM. Hopefully someone else will chime in using couplers. I spoke to Bigsis, he said he ran into the problem but was able to lower the upper crossmembers a little to compensate.

Don't buy the 8mm rod in China!
I bought it from 3 different supppiers - all were 7,93mm (which us 5/16 inch).
If you try the lm8uu bearings it they fit pretty ok but with a bit of wiggle in it.
Today my delivery from a local supplier arrived with the rods being 7,99mm (i have to double check both values with a micrometer this weekend) and the fitting was so much better.
The sealings are pushings the oil and you can not roll the bearing on the shaft but slide it smooth along.

comments.text:
Hello here,
The remix looks very good, but why have you removed the 10mm aluminum axes on X? It is the only moving part of the machine and therefore to avoid artifacts it must be as light as possible. I confess I do not understand this point.
Moreover it is what blocks me to mount this model compared to the original model, the parts being more massive we add weight for not much. The idea of ​​tech2c that was proven in his latest video demonstrates that weight greatly affects the print fault.
This can be compared to a delta printer, which has only the weight of the printhead, which is why delta prints are so successful.
The use of the 3030 profile is not necessarily justified for a volume of printing of 20x20x20 but it is the design that wants this I think especially to those who want to transform their base prusa.
I am also surprised the parts of the original is not compatible with this version.
Merite you finally the name of his elder ???
To meditate...
comments.author: Absolem

comments.text:
If you have print quality problems can be improved by rotating the stl file from 15 degrees to 30 degrees. Although it is not a correct remedy... ;)
Many people will make HypercubeEvolution from now on.
SCOTT_3D Designs stl files very cool (Shape and dimensions)
Tech2c 3D Printers are easy to change even for beginners.
Both tech2c and SCOTT_3D must be excellent creators.
Because many completed parts are not preferred for those who like to change but the concept of HypercubeEvolution will not shake.
comments.author: Absolem

comments.text: This is not a remix... every part is designed from scratch to be as simple and elegant as I could. I'm not going to enter into a debate about rods as this is a matter of preference. Tech2C even prooved that a "standard" steel rod setup can print without artifacts. Proof is in the printing and the results are excellent prints.
comments.author: Absolem

comments.text: While I agree with you, it wasn't about 'printing without artifacts', it was about 'printing as fast as you can without artifacts'. 8mm rods are fine if printing with slow to moderate speeds, but if you want to retain quality while printing at plus 60mm/s then steel rods are a huge no go. Which lets face it... the majority of people trying to build a CoreXY machine, are doing it because they are 'supposed' to be insanely fast printers even compared to a delta.
comments.author: SCOTT_3D

comments.text: What I mean is that I'm curious what software will upload the stl files to the hypercube and how to program the printer to know how to print the parts. Thanks
comments.author: acejas

comments.text: You'll need a motherboard to control all the parts of the printer.  The firmware you load (flash) onto the motherboard is what your PC software talks to to print parts.  Marlin firmware (marlinfw.org) is probably the most widely used firmware.  As to the PC side, you will need what you call a "slicer" which takes the model files (STL) and creates the g-code which is a bunch of instructions that the firmware understands. G-code tells the printer to set temperatures for the hot end and the print bed, where to move the hot end, how much and when to extrude plastic, etc.
comments.author: DavisFamily

comments.text: There are various PC side software you can use and best news most are free. Check out this article https://all3dp.com/1/best-free-3d-printing-software-3d-printer-program/

comments.text: Actually reconsidering this hotend. While it looks great I have done further reading. It seems the goal of a core xy is to keep the gantry as light as possible yet strong. Seems adding the extra weight of a direct drive may not be the best idea. I think I will just stick with a Bowden setup for the first machine and keep that weight down. I have a couple spare E3D extruders floating around anyways so it's a starting point.
comments.author: DarthOctane

comments.text:
Man that thing looks sick! As for the lengths of your X axis, It definitely would not hurt to add 25-50mm per side even if you don't use all of it. Down the road you may want to put a bigger bed on it, or who knows what else.
I think this is a great design as is, but I personally want to build something (almost) future proof to begin with so I don't have to rebuild it later as better things/ideas come around (and they will).
Most people that are even entertaining a build from scratch like this are very serious about this hobby and most likely don't mind the size of this machine, so what's a few more inches!
comments.author: DarthOctane

comments.text: You are correct and even adding an extra 50mm keeps the build to just under 20 inches by my calculation.

comments.text:
Since my Hypercube EVO is already printing for some days and I dont use any sensor at all, I can only say, that in my humble opinion you dont need any sensor. The DualZ axis construction is rock solid and does not bend in whatever direction at all.
I did level my bed by hand only once and that was exactly when the build was finished. Since then the EVO prints nearly 24/7 and I did not touch the level screws since then and prints are flawless.
Instead of the sensor I use an ordinary mechanical endstop with a adjustable screw. Plain and simple, but works without any problems.
comments.author: Thelorac

Hi Biggsis,

comments.text: I did NOT use normal endstops for X and Y, I used the optical ones, just as Scott suggested. Only for the Z-Axis I did not use the suggested inductive sensor, instead I used a mechanical endstop with an adjustable screw.

It's a 24v board isn't it?
What are your thoughts on carbon tits for the x axis to keep weight right down. Nearly an extra half kilo with steel rods in comparison
comments.author: Mochanic

comments.text:
Yes, it can run 12v or 24v, and has selectable outputs for fans 5v\12v\24v.
I'm not really sold on the carbon rods yet, I haven't seen any info on how well they hold up over time. Plus I know the tolerances are not nearly as good as the stainless or chromed shafts. (metal shafts are usually ground to make them perfectly round and to exact size) Carbon tube will have variances which will probably be ok for most applications, but I want a really ridged machine because not only am I putting an extruder on it, but also a laser engraver, and a high speed router for light carving/milling. (mainly for plastics) Thus the main reason I want to be able to totally enclose it.
comments.author: RoskaL

comments.text: I'm looking at the Duet Wifi and it looks like the fan option is either 5V or VIN (Which will either be 12V or 24V). So if you're running off 24V you do not get the option of 12V.
comments.author: Mochanic

comments.text:
I think you're right about the 12/24v thing. Its an easy fix either way. (cheap buck converter if you want to use 12v fans on a 24v supply)
As for the resistors, I have read that before too. It too is fairly straight forward to get optical end stops to work if that's what you choose to use. (but then again I have seen optical end stops that are compatible with both 3.3v and 5v.)

Do a little research of your own before deciding on which type to use.

Do yourself a favor and just build a 3030 evolution, it won't cost that much more.

Thanks for reply. Can I use direct extruder or only bowden ?

comments.author: Mochanic

comments.text:
A direct drive extruder just means that the filament drive mechanism is directly mounted to the motor shaft. Both bowden and direct extruders can be direct drive. A bowden extruder is not directly attached to the hot end. Instead, a tube extends from the extruder body to the hot end.
You can use whatever you want, after all you are building it from scratch!

comments.text: Can I ask why use a 24v power supply and down step everything and modify a ramps board? why not just run it on a 12v psu or use a mks board that can have 24v power....Thanks just trying to learn your thinking behind it...
comments.author: Telli

comments.text: I used a different approach with my EVO build: For the RAMPS/Arduino board I use a 12V 10A small power supply and for the bed I am using a 24V 30A power supply controlled by a Mosfet from the RAMPS board. Runs very nice and without problems. I am using at the moment a 213x213mm heatbed since I am waiting for the 300x300mm silicon bed, The small heatbed heats up to 70° Celsius in about 2 minutes with 24V. For the hotend I am still using the 12V from the small power supply. Like this both the hotend and heatbed are ready to print roughly at the same time.
comments.author: Telli

comments.text: That sounds like a much better idea for people using RAMPS/Arduino's
comments.author: Biggsis

comments.text: Good idea. Do the fans then run with 24V or how is that done?
comments.author: Mochanic

comments.text: Selectable via jumper.  5v/12v/24v
comments.author: Biggsis

comments.text: Using a 24v power supply for the heated bed and hot end makes them heat faster and is especially useful with the larger heated bed sizes such as 300mm x 300mm.  The ramps board requires 12v power for the arduino mega 2560 unless you power it from a separate supply.  When I build a larger printer I will use a 120v AC heated bed since there are MOSFET's available that will control it.
comments.author: Telli

comments.text:
You should get a bowden extruder my all means, It just makes more sense in a CoreXY printer. If you have to move the extra weight of the extruder motor with a direct approach, you loose the lightweight advantag (moves faster).
And I am currently working on an updated BOM, since I built the printer already and I know, what parts are needed and how many.
At the moment I am calibrating every axis of the printer and I have to develop a custom Z-endstop, since the inductive probe from the BOM turned out to not work through 3mm glass on the bed. And I prefer glass to print on.
So I either have to get an ugly, big and heavy 18mm inductive sensor and customize the X hotend mount, or (my preferred way) just use one optical switch on the side of the bed. With the rock solid bed constrution I think, I dont need any autolevel functionality, since leveling will be rarely needed anyway.

comments.text:
Very nice videos, Scott, you should link them here, nevertheless I am already beyond the point of the videos, mostly figured out myself how to do it, learned a few additional things from you though :).
I ran into the same issues with the IGUS bearings. The problem with them is always the same: If 2 of them are even slightly misaligned, they dont work smoothly anymore, the same goes for squeezing them. If you only squeeze them just a little bit (for example, just pressing them into the printed X-carriage), they also become very hard to move... That is why IGUS themselves (they are a german company where I am from and I asked them) recommends only using them in a pillow block, like this they can move just a little bit to be perfectly aligned.... Maybe I will someday redesign the EVO X and Y carriage to use pillow blocks for the bearings.
For this build I went back to the standard LM even if they are quite noisy and for the Y-Axis I used LM10LUU with 55mm length instead of 2 LM10UU.
The rest of the build went quite smoothly, I am wiring the electronics for a test at the moment using a Ramps 1.4 board with 8825 stepper drivers and I have a request: Would you care to share your Marlin "Configuration.h" file with the community?
Thanks in advance and keep up the nice work, that is very much appreciated, I was always hesitating to build the original Hypercube, but with the Evolution you created a very nice piece of machinery, that I immediately started to build. I am not finished with the printer yet, but I already love, how sturdy and nice and clean it looks.
comments.author: Biggsis

comments.text: Hi, The tensioning system uses M3 brass inserts for all of the clamp screws and tensioning system. Similarly the extruder is mounted with a single screw from the rear, and a M3 insert in the extruder mount itself. This is to allow for quick removal and to date has worked without issue. There is also a "standard" hole pattern on the face of the X carriage. This is for the locating pins but these can also be tapped and other extruder mounts fitted to this.

comments.text: I seen the same thing while printing but my print end correctly... what's your problem?
comments.author: giftyakapatch

comments.text: Interesting. I have had no issues printing the carriage. I use Simplify3D, 0.2mm height and 0.4mm width. Does slic3r slice ok and just failing during printing or does slicing fail?
comments.author: giftyakapatch

comments.text: for stablity the direction of the extrusions should be circular to the bearings... so it should be printed vertical rather than horizontal.
comments.author: SCOTT_3D

comments.text: Ok, you may have another problem. If the bearings are too tight, ie needing the printed part needing to flex open more, then this could cause the breakage. The bearings should be a snug fit into the carriage and not need a large force or bending of the part to make them fit. Check the overall size of the part. If your calibration or extrusion multiplier is out then the part will be oversize and the bearing hole too small.
comments.author: giftyakapatch

comments.text:
I am using a Delta printer ... The calibration is 0.01mm on 20mm tolerance on all 3 dimensions... I hope the calibration is good enough ...
Printout with 0.2mm layer height, pla at 210 degree's Celsius with 80mm/s.
comments.author: SCOTT_3D

comments.text: Yes, you cannot ask for much better than that! I have never printed with PLA so cannot comment as to it strenght. I have had no issues with the part printed in PETG. So is it the outside edge breaking off? I could adjust the design if we need some more wall thickness there. Another mm would not hurt. Thoughts?

comments.text: the problem is for SCOTT_3D design i can´t use carbon tubing because the X Carriage is made for clip an LM8UU bearing in and i think this will not work on carbon tubing ?!
comments.author: Elstak

comments.text:
Why not?
Carbon tube is like steel rod but much lighter, you can easily use 8x6 up to 4-500mm and 8x4 up to 900mm w/ a safety factor of 5 or 6 before the tube start bending. But you cant use the LM8UU it will damage the tube surface. You can buy original IGUS 2° generation solid bearing for 2-3 $ each or the clone of the 1st generation on aliexpress for 0.5$ i raccomand to buy the original from amazon (the second generation have little wings inside; the 1st gen have big wings).

title: Case for CHIP and LiPo battery - Lego compatible

description.text:
This is a case for Next Thing Co.'s C.H.I.P. computer. It has a screw hole, which is compatible with the screw that comes with CHIP. There are holes for Lego Technic beams on either side of the case, Lego studs on the top, and the bottoms of Lego plates in each bottom corner. The case measures exactly 8x8 Lego studs. All side ports are exposed, but the CHIP is hidden from view in the front and back of the case, giving the case a more professional look. Ventilation for the bottom side of CHIP is achieved through the bottom row of Technic holes on either side, as well as two slits in the bottom of the case, designed to be reminiscent of similar slits on the bottom of the LEGO Mindstorms NXT Intelligent Brick. Despite a specifically designed thinner wall for it, due to the slight (~1mm) overhang of the MicroUSB port on CHIP, the CHIP must go into the case "one end at a time." The entire case is the height of 5 Lego plates, but due to a design limitation of the bottom of the case, the case must be placed on four 1x2 plate "stilts" in each corner to fit on top of an existing Lego model. Because the case does not have a top (although the user can build one with Legos if they so desire), GPIO ports are exposed in the case.

EDIT: I have designed a companion battery case for this case. It was designed to fit the battery in my PocketCHIP. It is a similar style, except it is four plates tall, has only one row of Technic pieces, and has two full rows on the bottom for Lego studs. Also, it does not have full rows of studs on the top. This allows it to snap into the bottom of the CHIP case, as well as encouraging the user to design for adequate ventilation. If the user would like to have full rails on the top, they can accomplish this using 2 1x8 Lego plates. Although this case was designed to attach to the bottom of the CHIP case, it can also go on top. (If you want the Technic holes to line up in this configuration, however, it is necessary to add 2 1x8 Lego plates between the cases.) To insert the battery into the case, first thread the wires through the slot and then fit the battery into the enclosure.

I use this with mindjacker to control a Lego Mindstorms brick.

author: Wes8

description.text:
Voici la version du panneau de commande qui équipera la box dédiée à ma « DiscoeasyEVO+ » sur laquelle j’ai poussé les murs puisque les dimensions de son plateau est 46x30cm. Il me fallait donc un panneau digne de ce nom.

J’ai donc repris la première config embarquant les 2 raspberry pi de mon Octopi+ pour les mettre en version panel.

J’ai ajouté un panneau pour accueillir l’écran de commande de l’imprimante en déportant le lecteur de carte SD en façade (car même si je m’en sers de façon homéopathique, c’est toujours bon de l’avoir en cas de caprice de la framboise…)
Vous trouverez aussi un boitier pour la carte relais que j’ai fixé au dos du panel Octoprint ainsi que le support du PID. (A savoir que vous pourrez vous passer de ce dernier grâce à la nouvelle version de l’excellent « enclosure plugin » disponible sur Octoprint depuis quelques jours. Mais comme je l’avais déjà, autant s’en servir…)
Sur ce dernier, j’ai ajouté 2 emplacements pour mettre 2 boutons type arcade que j’ai assigné à la lumière et l’autre au lancement de la vidéo du second raspberry.

Bien évidemment, vous aurez compris que j’adore ce qui brille avec toutes ces LED mais j’aime savoir ce qui fonctionne sans avoir à me balader dans les menus d’octoprint pendant une impression.

Je reste dispo pour toutes question si le projet vous tente…

la pieuvre en déco passe mal en 0.20 sur le panel raspberry(cf photo), prevoyez de l'imprimer en 0.10, cela va beaucoup mieux.

Printer:

DiscoEasy 200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

33%

Notes:

j'ai imprimé tout les panneaux sur champ pour économiser le PLA et pour réduire les risques de warping au vu de la taille des pièces.
Chose surprenante, j'ai sorti les plus grands panneaux dans le sens de la hauteur en reduisant la vitesse à 50 mm/s et c'est nickel.

This is a 2ft. x 2ft. vacuum table designed for a CNCRouterparts "Benchtop Pro" CNC Router machine.

Process (in a nutshell):

  1. Obtain your MDF wood
  2. Load the file in Fusion 360 (free for hobbyists)
  3. Select/create your tool and regenerate tool-paths (Note: this could take a while. Fusion 360 just does not like this tool path. My computer uses up to 5GB RAM and 5-10 minutes to make any changes to the main air chamber tool path. )
  4. Process output files (keep operations separate)
  5. Load the file into Mach3 (licensed)
  6. Set your "zero" for X and Y but follow the NOTICE below for setting your Z-zero
  7. Run operation to cut main chamber
  8. Run operation to cut vacuum port
  9. Flip material, re-zero
  10. Run operation to cut "guide holes" - these holes are not through the material
  11. Assemble using duct tape and shop vac
  12. Fasten to work table
  13. Selectively drill out holes for your media size using a cordless drill and drill bit
  14. Enjoy!

NOTICE: You must cut the main air chamber using 2 passes. The file included does NOT do this automatically because my computer could not render the two passes without crashing. To achieve 2 passes, simply calibrate your Z-zero to 0.25 above your material on the first pass, and then calibrate Z-zero to true material top on your second pass.

Bolt Holes (recommended) can be added by creating a sketch on the material border, or by manually drilling. Bolts will keep both pieces of MDF square and tight to the table, while clamps may result in some slippage.

See pictures for more detail.

Required material:

  • air filter mask, eye and ear protection
  • two pieces 2x2' MDF, 1" thick
  • duct tape - for sealing the two tables pieces together around the outer edge
  • shop vac - I used a small Rigid-brand "5HP Max" shop vac
  • bolts, clamps or other fastening hardware
  • cordless drill and 1/8" drill bit - for drilling out guide holes to match your media size

Optional material:

  • M8x60 bolts, washers and t-slot inserts - for "Benchtop Pro" machine
  • glue - for gluing the two pieces of MDF together around the outer border and also across all of the inner support "cubes." This can be achieved by spreading glue, sandwiching the two pieces together and then clamping or applying even force (e.g. weight) across the entire surface on a LEVEL surface. I opted NOT to glue the two pieces at first however I did notice that the two MDF pieces have a slight air gap between them which could result in uneven cutting with vacuum pressure changes. However, I'm doing through-cutting and not engraving so I am OK with this, plus this is just an experiment for now.

Note STL file will not work, and is only uploaded to satisfy Thingiverse programming. Fusion 360 does NOT seem to export in any formats compatible with Thingiverse.

The slider on our cupboard door broke, and made the door hard to open/close. Since the said slider was made about 50 years ago, it hasn't done too badly, however, due to its age, it is no longer available. While we are going to renovate in the next year, that is a little to long to wait. In steps the REPRAP I built with the kids (I built... they said "when's it going to be ready... can we print X with it?"). Half an hour with FreeCAD, and a check on NetFabb, and I was printing a replacement. A little cleaning up (I'm still tuning the printer, but it is much better now than it was when I printed this), and we fitted it. Worked perfectly the first time!
Not that I expect anybody else to be able to use this thing, but it is yet another case of REPRAP to the rescue, and yet another "wife acceptance point" in its favour.
Print (with support... doesn't use much support, but it does need it) and attach if you just happen to have a similar door slider give way.
These parts are a 7-axis manipulator. Sequence of parts are base-shoulder-upper_arm-forearm-J5-J6-J7.

A laser-cutter that uses only 3 different 3D printed parts.
The design is based on our "big plotter" and the "selfdrawing painting". The laser head is wireless. The power to the laser head is delivered trough the smooth rods

For the assembly you need:
4x Linear axle holder
2x Carriage
1x Laser carrier

4x Nema 17 stepper motor
4x 8mm smooth rod (length is up to you (max 1 meter recommended))
4x M8 threaded rod (length is up to you (max 1 meter recommended))
8x LM8UU linear bearing
16x M8 nut
3x set of timing belt with pulley (length is dependable of the length rod you choose)

1x 12mm laser (http://www.banggood.com/1000mw-Bluish-Violet-Laser-Head-Parts-405nm-For-Engraver-DIY-Engraving-Machine-p-1092171.html)
1x 12V to 5v adapter (We used a car/phone charger)
2x 40mm fan (one for the laser and one for the controller)
1x power supply (12V 5A)
1x GRBL shield v3+adruino uno (other cnc related controllers should work)
and the wires to feed the stepper drivers, the controller-board, power-supply and a USB cable.

description.text:
I am using a 13" tablet as a sheet music reader. To work on the files I have to synchronize the tablet with my PC. The glaring screen of the tablet doesn't work well when laying flat on my desk. I need a stand that can hold the big tablet safe and secure but i also small enough to fit into a bag. I decided to design a 2 part stand than easily comes apart and can be stored flat.

Nothing fancy, just functional. I used Fusion 360 to create the design and printed it out without any issues. No supports or rafts have been needed.

The Stands works exactly as envisioned and will be another practical application of 3D printed parts in my home and office.

Getting the collapsible ladder out of the way to de-clutter the garage was another small 3D printing project that worked out fine. I designed the hook around the plastic dowels and screws I already had and created a straightforward design to work on my ladder. Probably it will work on other ladder models too. Or the design can be used to be modified to fit other items.

I printed 2 of the hooks that have been designed in Fusion 360. For strength I used a 50% infill with a 200mil resolution.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Ladder holder

Using Fusion 360 I designed this hook around the ladder and the dowels and screws I had available. It was important to accommodate for the fins of the dowels to prevent turning of the dowel when the screw is turned. A simple countersunk hole would not have worked.

I loved the Pac-Man ghost, but it seemed off without some eyes, so I added some. I also re-created a blue (power-pellet pac-man-fleeing) ghost as well. There was another one out there, but this version is more consistent with the original and the mouth has been re-created to minimize overhang when printing.

Boo!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Hi all, I was looking for a quick disconnect mount/dismount for my new J-Tech Photonics 2.8w Laser. I liked the concept done by Droneme, but it wasn't a good fit for me. The part that mounts to the laser is the same file as his, untouched. I made a custom bracket to connect to the side of the Openbuilds spindle mount. I used the controller housing from Droneme for a temporary solution to mount the board to the side of the V-Slot rail. I just drilled holes in it to mount it.

This is the first part I've made and submitted. Please let me know if you have any questions. I have the file in fusion 360 if anyone needs it or would like to see a change.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Supports:

No

Orientation that I printed the parts. This kept the sections that slide together precise. Parts fit together snug. Mounted to the side of the Openbuilds spindle. Another photo mounted to the spindle. The final revision of this I made the part the entire width of the Openbuilds bracket (not seen in photo). Top View. I used a pc power supply connector for the quick disconnect. Two wires for the fan and two for the laser. I used the controller housing from Droneme as a temporary mount. Will redesign this at some point whenever I find its forever home.

title: Horizontal Thread Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Horizontal Sewing Machine Thread Holder

This Horizontal Thread Holder is used to convert from a vertical holder to Horizontal to reduce the tension. Some spools are designed to be used in this fashion, specifically for delicate sewing. Using the spool in the vertical direction adds tension every time the machine pulls on the thread causing some delicate fabrics to buckle/pucker.

This converter works for spool less than 30mm think.

M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

20%

Video game cartridge cleaner, just add pads.

Here is a base card to build your very own cartridge cleaners. All you need to do is cut up some soft cleaner pads and paste the on both ends of the card. One side is intended to have the cleaner fluid and the other is the dry end which you use to wipe the pins dry.

Depending on how thick pads you use, this card will fit NES, SNES and Gameboy carts. I have no Sega carts to test this with, but it should fit right in there.

description.text: Attachment piece for pixel strips, used to replace the bottom attachment piece of ChristmasLightShow.com pixel attachment hardware. This piece is designed to slide over EMT after the CLS supplied bolt has been installed. The bolt then attaches to the other hardware piece on the pixel strip. This allows the user to customize the tension on each pixel string, yet attaches the pixel strip to the base in a more secure way than with the piece provided by CLS in their kit. Design is for 1"OD EMT, but can be sized for any pipe used for your base.

description.text:
I didn't like the amount of movement of the actual tensioner on the designs which make use of 3mm bolts so I designed this one with 8mm screws which push directly onto the X-carriage rods.

NOTE: If the bolt fits too loosely then adjust your extrusion % or upscale the bolt by 1%.

13/08/2017: v2 has a bigger 11mm opening to accommodate a 9mm teethed idler pulley wheel. These are the ones I used: http://www.ebay.com/itm/301834183849

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

25%

In scad You can specify length,radius,arc:
straight(150);//150mm straight piece
curveR(500,22.5);//curve right with 500mm radius and 22.5degrees arc
switch1(500,30);//switch to left and right with 500mm radius and 30degrees arc

Notes:

For adhesion I used about 7 loops of skirt at distance 0.1mm.

description.text: Power supply holder for Kossel 3D printers (with 2020 extruded aluminium frame)
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gPrQBVyjVld-2020-power-supply-holder

This is the filament holder I use beside my Flashforge Finder 3D printer. I use this when using filament reels that are too big for the printer filament holder.

I print the leg on my Flashforge Finder in one piece. The reel/spool hub is designed to fit a reel with 53,5mm opening, and it "clicks on". The reels I have designed this for is from 3Dnet.no. With the hub attached to the spool, a 100mm steel rod is inserted through the center and it rests and rotates on the leg structure.

comments.text: This is for the 1kg rolls? (that they don't sell anymore) Or are they for the 3kg rolls?
comments.author: Tveito

comments.text:
The A-frame fits most spools in general I think, it's 90mm wide on the inside and 130mm from tabletop to center of spool axis.
I see now that the spools I use in the pictures are not the same as the ones for sale at 3Dnet.no. In the description for 3DNet PLA 1.75 0.75kg the inner diameter of the spool is 54mm, which should fit the hub nicely, but I'm not sure of how the 'snap function' would work on this spool.

This is a clip I made after buying an HP bench power supply with a broken meter clip.  The meter was flopping around inside the supply, which made for a low price on eBay.

author: josemont

description.text: made to extend the stock spool holder for the anet A8 so now will hold 2 spools :)

The Kontinuum Garden is a highly automated, rotating hydroponic system, designed to be almost entirely 3d-printed. It's a true food-factory. Extremely water and energy efficient, and equipped with a simple DIY LED-growlight, and a 3D-printed pump system. The capacity will be for 60 plants. We are making the Garden because we want to change the way people think about food.
We want to use 3d-printer technology to make sustainable automated food-production available for all people, everywhere. Our hope is that the garden will help people around the world be more independent and grow their own food. We are also building the printer which will make this.
The "Kontinuum Reprap" is our design for a reprap with a print area of roughly 1 meter squared, allowing it to print one garden in only 4 prints. We are funding the development of the Kontinuum Garden and Kontinuum Reprap on Indiegogo.com/Kontinuumgarden
Please go check it out.

We're trying to slice these files right now for a printer with a 1mm aperture hot-end - we'll let you know how it went.<

[EDIT: The large wheel sliced on my tiny netbook in +/- 4 hours. The paths look fine, except it didn't make the last solid layers - just kept making walls and infill right until the end. Hmmmm - Not sure what the problem is, time to try some different settings.] If anyone has experience with large prints, we would love some pointers as to the possible problems we might run into. Slicing, printer mechanics, plastic, whatever. Or hey! If you have a 1x1m 3d-printer, you can have a go at printing it yourself....

description.header: Part by part explanation of the Garden:

"KontinuumGarden Rail 08"
This is the main rail, of which the Kontinuum Garden uses 15.
It features an easy and practical "snap"system, which is used to attach the rails to the two wheels.
Measurements are: 600mm x 100mm x 28mm.

"KG Large Gear Wheel 16.stl"
This is the wheel that makes the garden turn.
The gear has 313 teeth, and will mesh with a smaller 31 tooth gear on the It has 15 holes, where the rails snap in.
Measurements are:
Diameter 1000mm
Height 63mm
width 75mm

"KG Large Wheel 16.stl"
This is the passive wheel, which sits opposite from the large gear. This might still be upgraded with a primitive rail cutout to keep it centered.
It also has 15 holes, where the rails snap in.
Measurements are:
Diameter 1000mm
Height 63mm
width 75mm
description.text: "KG Box 42.stl"

description.header:
This is the box that holds the individual plants in the Kontinuum Garden.
It is open on one side, so you just put your growth medium and seedling in, and then snap on the lid. The whole box then snaps in between two rails of the garden
This is the first part of the full sized garden that we have actually printed. (on a Prusa, with 0.4mm layer thickness and no infill)
The design is still a work in progress, as we need to reduce the amount of plastic (thickness of some of the walls etc) to get the springiness we need for the snap system.
Measurements are:
Width: 11 cm
Height: 9.5 cm
Depth: 9.5 cm
(Inner measurements are roughly 8x8x8 cm)
description.text:
"KG Base 22.stl" This is the main base of the Kontinuum Garden, which supports everything else.
This model still needs quite a lot of clean-up before it's ready for printing, and the design will still need to be adjusted to fit the gearing and watering mechanisms etc. Measurements are:
Length: 90 cm
Width: 75 cm
Height 25 cm

.AOI-files.
These files contain all the elements that went into making the pieces for the garden.
If you want to tinker, just look inside one of the "ORG Objects" nulls. All the geometry, splines, booles, arrays and whatnot are in there, organized with the first basic object at the bottom, so you can work your way upwards and make the adjustments you want.
Enjoy :-)

update : I found the PLA a little bit slippery, don't have yet TPU or flexible filament, so I sprayed them with Rubber Leakseal. The Pads hold better on the TX and especially hands too !

Here's a set of hand pad that I created to hold well this thin i6 transmitter from Flysky.
I printed them without any support, standing, be careful there's not much touching bottom layer, you can try adding manual support.

Polygon look is wanted.

Designed more for Thumbs Pilots, maybe the configuration is not the best for Pinching.

I drilled holes on my tx with a 2.6ish mm mesh than screwed metal 3mm hex screw.

If you want to try first, I could imagine first print it as vase mode maybe.

description.text:
Needed some protection while grinding, sanding, cutting.

You can stop the print or cut the top if you want an easier access to install large wheels.
If you just need the Dremel nut, or have limited protection, stop the print or cut accordingly.

WARNING: A jerk made two totally different "remixes" just to bring some attention to his creations while failing the purpose of them.

This POS angry like hell by my comments on his poor things and pitiful remixes of my own designs for which he dares asking for TIPS. ended up accusing me of stealing designs

I liked the idea of the said dust cover but didn't make it as it was for a flexible, wasn't sturdy enough for my need, didn't have the nut integrated, was not long enough for some grinding wheels .... I can't use the Dremel nut anyway as I have a different chuck.

So I designed one of my own for my needs.

It can also be cut, print stopped, to get just the nut or a partial protection.

The only real similitude is the well rounded corners done to be able to print without support.

It is as similar to it as to any protection for angle grinder, big or small, etc...! Dremel sells one. There are plenty of other Dremel protections even here, all similar. Same purpose usually leads to same shape. Public domain therefore.

Hardly a remix then. Otherwise everything are remixes.

BTW there are many linear bearing housings published here similar to mine, and I don't accuse them of copying mine as they differ in the most important details. :) The devil is in the details !

But people who "remixes" poorly to slander, are despicable. See below for an expert..

I like things when they bring something original, ingenious,smart, new but not always as some of them I had seen or used in the past.

PS: For the creatures posting below, genuine remixes of monkeys (the "cosmetic" changes don't justify a separate classification), I don't care for what you utter (think is beyond your abilities). I just find funny you teamed up like crippled bonobos to spoil the comments thread here and others. How about publishing real working things even remixes I won't have to criticize ? Some jerks even have nothing to show, just insults.

i really like the coreXY and the D-bot design so i built my own with a few modifications and a few designs of my own. the build space is 330x330x400. the system is controlled by the MKS Sbase running smoothieware with a full 24v system. heated bed is a silicon mat 24v 400w on 1/4" mic6 aluminum and a mosfet. I designed the PSU holder, LED remote control box and holder and spool holder. i redesigned the controller box, touchscreen box and mount. the whole build took me two months but i was in no rush and I really enjoyed the process. the only issues i have run into is the Z axis tilting because there are only two lead screws. three screws seems excessive so i would like to further design the wheel guides to assist in leveling the Z axis.
